The synthesis and utilization of defect-rich biomass carbon catalysts with varying Co concentrations and incorporated Ce in CH4-CO2 reforming were investigated. The catalytic performance of these catalysts was found to increase with higher Co content, reaching its optimum at a Co concentration of 20 %. The presence of Ce as a promoter improved the utilization of Co precursors and enhanced the dispersion of Co sites at defective structures on the catalyst surface. The confined space within the defective structures restricted the growth of Co particles, resulting in smaller and more uniformly dispersed Co particles on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the introduction of Ce species influenced the oxygen environment on the catalyst surface. XPS analysis confirmed that the addition of Ce led to an increase in the chemisorbed oxygen content, enhancing the catalyst's ability to activate CO2. The increased percentage of chemisorbed oxygen, coupled with improved CO2 activation capacity, contributed to the Co-Ce bimetallic catalyst's ability to resist carbon deposition. The Co-Ce bimetallic catalyst demonstrated exceptional stability and performance in CH4-CO2 reforming due to its enhanced metal dispersion, reduced metal particle size, and improved CO2 activation capacity. The incorporation of Ce as a promoter played a crucial role in achieving these desirable catalytic properties. Introduction The technology of carbon dioxide reforming of methane (DRM) involves the production of valuable syngas from CH4 and CO2, which provides a promising method for achieving the goal of carbon neutrality [1–4]. Through the process of Fischer-Tropsch reaction, the obtained syngas can be used to make other valuable chemicals [5,6]. DRM reaction provides a technological pathway for the integrated use of two major greenhouse gas resources and the conversion of two difficult-to activated small molecules. It has multiple research values of environmental, economy and sustainability. However, the challenging problem in the industrial development of DRM is carbon deposition and metal sintering on the catalyst [7–9]. Nickel and cobalt are currently the two commonly used active metal when combining both cost and catalytic performance [10,11]. In contrast to Co-based catalysts, Ni-based catalysts have better performance yet are highly susceptible to deactivation on account of metal sintering and carbon deposition within short period of time [12–15]. The higher oxygen affinity of the active metal Co facilitates the oxidation of CHX species [16]. In the DRM reaction, Co-based catalysts have demonstrated effective anti-carbon deposition abilities. Thus, the development of a highly active cobalt-based catalyst is of utmost urgency for the successful industrialization of DRM. Numerous methods to improve the performance of DRM catalysts have been revealed by researchers, which mainly include designing suitable active metal particle sizes and enhancing the dispersion of active metals [17–21]. Rational development of a series of domain-limited structures is an effective way to obtain suitable metal particle sizes. For example, Qu et al. [3] developed Ni/kaolinite catalysts with sandwich-structured by interaction-etching strategy. Compared to original Ni/kaolinite catalysts, the sandwich-structured Ni/kaolinite catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic performance during the 100 h DRM stability test, owing to its lower Ni particle size and stronger metal-support interaction. Lu et al. [22] prepared Ni@HSS catalyst with a novel yolk-shell structure by one-pot method. The SiO2 shell served a dual purpose: not only did it limit the growth of Ni particles, but it also effectively prevented their aggregation during the DRM reaction. Cao et al. [23] successfully introduced defective structures on h-BN by combining h-BN and urea mechanical ball milling. Ni/h-BNNS catalysts with small Ni particle size were obtained when h-BNNS with defect-rich structure was loaded with active metal Ni. And the interfacial electronic effect between Ni and defective structures improved the metal-support interactions. As can be observed, a certain geometry can be introduced into the support to achieve metal particle confinement. It can be seen that the restriction of metal particles can be achieved through a specific geometric structure, which not only restricts the growth of metal particles to obtain a smaller size of active metal, but also effectively avoids the sintering of metal in the DRM reaction. Defect-rich structured carbon materials have been widely used in adsorption and electrocatalysis [24–26]. Unpaired electrons at the defective structure are significant in gas adsorption and activation [24,27]. It is foreseen that the defect-rich carbon material can be used as Co-based catalyst support for DRM reaction, and the defective structure can both confine the Co particles and simulate the gas adsorption and activation. An active metal such as Co with a lower particle size and excellent dispersion undoubtedly possesses superior catalytic ability for the DRM. Introducing a promoter is an effective method to enhance the dispersibility of active metals and improve their catalytic performance [28,29]. The researchers discovered that using CeO2 as a catalyst promoter not only enhances the dispersion of metal, but also exhibits high oxygen storage and rapid oxygen transfer capabilities, accelerating the adsorption and activation of the feed gas [30–33]. The DRM reaction is promoted by an increase in CO2 concentration on the catalyst surface [34,35]. Additionally, it is not enough to ensure a good dispersion of Co in order for Co-based catalysts to exhibit superior catalytic performance. To ensure that Co particles do not aggregate during the DRM, it is crucial to limit their size. Our previous researchers have shown that the introduction and removal of nitrogen atoms in carbon materials is an effective method for producing defective structures, which creates favorable conditions for restricting Co particle size. Therefore, this study intended to introduce Ce as a promoter in Co-based defect-rich biomass carbon system and comprehensively enhance the dispersion of Co particles. A series of Co-based defect-rich biomass carbon catalysts with different Co contents and Ce as a promoter were prepared by impregnation method. Several characterizations including BET, TEM, H2-TPD, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR, XRD and TG were performed to understand the impact of Ce addition on the physicochemical properties of Co-based biomass carbon catalysts. Results revealed that Ce assisted Co to be anchored in the defect sites and also regulated the oxygen environment on the catalyst surface. Thus, Co-Ce bimetallic catalysts exhibited the upper level of catalytic capability. Experimental Sample preparation First, defect-rich Y-NC support was prepared by pyrolysis of a mixture of soybean meal and melamine followed by the addition of defect-inducing agent KOH. The supplementary data described the specific technique in detail. Y-NC-XCo and Y-NC-XCo-YCe were obtained by impregnation method. First, Y-NC was acquired by the previous method, the specific synthesis steps is shown in the supporting information. Next, a specific mass of Y-NC was stirred with Co(NO3)2 aqueous solution at 25 °C for 6 h, followed by drying in the oven at 110 °C for half a day. The resulting sample was subsequently calcined under N2 protection at 600 °C for 120 min. And the obtained powder was recorded as Y-NC-XCo, where X was the nominal loading of Co. The values of X were 10, 15, 20, respectively. Y-NC-20Co-5Ce was obtained by further loading Ce from Y-NC-20Co. A certain mass of Y-NC-20Co was stirred with Ce(NO3)2 aqueous solution at 25 °C for 6 h and subsequently dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h. The conditions during roasting were consistent with those described previously. Preparation of Y-NC was seen in the supporting information (SI1). The preparation procedure was shown in Scheme 1 . Catalytic performance test Three grams of quartz sand was diluted with 0.5 g of catalyst and placed in a quartz tube that has a length of 500 mm (I.D. 25 mm). The mole ratio of CH4 and CO2 was set at 1:1 with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 14,400 mL g−1 h−1. The gas reactants and products were analyzed by GC-950 gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD detector. The catalyst activity tests were conducted in two temperature intervals to evaluate the performance of the catalyst. In the first temperature interval, the range was set from 650 °C to 850 °C. After each 50 °C temperature increment, the temperature was held steady for 30 min to allow the catalyst to reach equilibrium and test its catalytic properties. Similarly, in the second temperature interval, the range was reversed, starting from 850 °C and decreasing to 650 °C. The same protocol was followed, maintaining each temperature reduction for 30 min to monitor the catalyst's performance at different temperatures. The catalyst catalytic performance versus reaction time was tested at 800 °C. Characterization of the catalysts was seen in the supporting information (SI2). The conversion of CH4 and CO2, H2/CO, H2 and CO selectivity were calculated as follows: X C H 4 ( % ) = F i n , C H 4 − F o u t , C H 4 F i n , C H 4 × 100 % X C O 2 ( % ) = F i n , C O 2 − F o u t , C O 2 F i n , C O 2 × 100 % H 2 / C O = F o u t , H 2 F o u t , C O × 100 % H 2 Selectivity = F o u t , H 2 2 F i n , C H 4 × 100 % C O Selectivity = F o u t , C O F i n , C H 4 + F i n , C O 2 × 100 % C a r b o n b a l a n c e = F o u t , C H 4 + F o u t , C O 2 + F o u t , C O F i n , C H 4 + F i n , C O 2 where, Fin and Fout were the inlet and outlet gas flow rate of different gas. Results and discussion The physical structural properties of fresh catalysts The BET surface area and physical structure characteristics of the prepared samples were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption technique, which were described in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . It can be seen the adsorption-desorption isotherms of the four prepared samples were typical combination of type Ⅰ and type Ⅳ [36,37]. In accordance with the IUPAC categorization, this indicated that the catalysts contain both microporous and mesoporous structures [38]. Table 1 exhibited that the BET surface area and pore volume of the catalyst decreased with the increment of Co loading. This was ascribed to the tendency of the active metal Co poles to load at the pore structure of Y-NC. And it must be mentioned that the BET surface area and the volume of pores are almost the same for Y-NC-20Co and Y-NC-20Co-5Ce. The loading of more metals didn't cause a remarkable decline in the BET surface area and the pore volume of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce. It was justifiable that the presence of the additive Ce was very beneficial for enhancing the distribution of Co particles and reducing the particle size of Co. The ICP test results also confirmed this. Compared to Y-NC-20Co, Y-NC-20Co-5Ce had a higher loading of Co. The further loading of Ce not only contributed to enhance the dispersibility of Co particles and the reduction of Co particle size, but also improved the utilization of metal precursors. As shown in Fig. 2 , TEM was employed to further study the impact of Ce addition on the size and dispersibility of Co particles. The Co particle size on Y-NC-20Co and Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalysts was computed by counting 60 metallic Co particles. And it was discovered that Ce promoter apparently reduced the size of Co. This was consistent with the results of BET combined with ICP analysis. Relatively small metal particles facilitated the exhibition of more catalytic sites to enhance the performance of the catalyst [39]. These results all implied that Y-NC-20Co-5Ce has better DRM catalytic performance. The HRTEM technology provided further insight into the crystal lattice and micro-morphology of catalysts. As presented in Fig. 2e, the average crystalline phase spacing of Y-NC-20Co catalyst was 0.3352 nm, indicating the presence of CoO (220) in the catalyst. As for Y-NC-20Co-5Ce, the crystalline phase distance of 0.2956 nm suggested the existence of Co3O4 (422) (Fig. 2f). It was revealed that Co2+ and Co3+ are presented in the Co species of the catalyst. The H2-TPD results of the Y-NC-20Co and Y-NC-20Co-5Ce are presented in Fig. 3 and Table 2 . The dispersion and particle dimension of active metal Co were measured from the hydrogen desorption. The H2 desorption peak temperature of Y-NC-20Co was higher than that of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce, as can be observed in Fig. 3. This indicated that the reaction product H2 was more easily desorbed on the surface of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce. This maintained a high degree of agreement with the TEM results. It is confirmed by these results that Ce has a significant contribution in enhancing the dispersibility of Co particles. The chemical structural properties of fresh catalysts XRD technology was explored to estimate the crystal configurations of all catalysts, and the outcomes of all catalysts were plotted in Fig. 4 a. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.6° and 44.8° represented CoO and Co3O4, respectively [40,41]. For Y-NC-20Co-5Ce, the height of the characteristic peaks of CoO and Co was markedly smaller than that of the other three catalysts. It was further demonstrated that Ce served as a structural stimulator enhances the dispersibility of Co particles. In particular, Y-NC-20Co-5Ce did not appear a clear diffraction peak of CeO2, which was caused by the low loading of Ce that was homogeneously distributed on the support. XPS characterization of the catalysts was performed to learn more about the surface chemical components of the catalysts together with the impact of Ce introduction on the electronic state of Co. Fig. 4b presented the XPS spectra of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 core levels for all catalysts, and they can be divided into two peaks. This indicated that the Co species on the catalyst surface include Co2+ and Co3+. As shown in Table 3 , the value of Co2+/Co3+ increment with Co additive by reaching a maximum value with the incorporation of Ce, which indicated that the presence of Ce facilitates the development of Co2+. As shown XPS pattern of O1s in Fig. 4c, the O species can be separated into three different species, which were the lattice oxygen species (Oα) with binding energy around 530.3 eV, the chemisorbed oxygen species (Oβ) around 531.8 eV, and the carbonyl oxygen species (Oγ) around 533.4 eV [42–44]. The Oβ/Oα+Oβ values for each catalyst were outlined in Table 3. Noticeably, the percentage of chemisorbed oxygen enlarged with the increment of Co loading. The incorporation of Ce further affected the oxygen environment, and Y-NC-20Co-5Ce had the highest percentage of chemisorbed oxygen among all catalyst. The results of the XPS split-peak fit of Ce 3d were located in Fig. 4d. Ce 3d contains two spin orbitals, Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2, corresponding to the u and v peaks, respectively. The peaks of u′ and v′ were credited to Ce3+, the peaks of u, u″, u′′′ and v, v″, v′′′ were credited to Ce4+ [45–48]. The formation process of Ce3+ was correlated with the creation of oxygen vacancies, so the percentage of chemisorbed oxygen of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce was improved after the addition of Ce [48–51]. The H2-TPR results were located in the Fig. 4e. All fresh catalysts appeared two reduction peaks mainly at 300–400 °C and 500–600 °C. The former was the reduction peak of Co3+ and the latter was the reduction peak of Co2+ [52]. It was demonstrated that the Co species of the catalysts consist of Co2+ and Co3+, confirming the results of the XPS analysis. Fig. 4f displayed the H2 consumption of all fresh catalysts. With increased Co loading, the H2 consumption of the samples improved. And the participation of Ce enlarged the H2 consumption of Y-NC-20Co. Fig. 4g displayed the Raman spectra of all fresh catalysts. The D-band at 1341 cm−1 corresponds to disordered carbon, the G-band at 1580 cm−1 corresponds to graphitic carbon, and the broad 2D peak at 2680 cm−1 belonged to long-range ordered carbon [53–55]. The ID/IG values were used to describe the degree of defects in carbon materials. From Fig. 4h, the ID/IG values of the catalysts decreased with increasing metal loading, which reflected that the tendency of Co and Ce metal precursors to load the defective structures of carbon materials. This was consistent with the literature [48]. In addition, the microcrystalline composition of the metal oxides on the catalyst surface was analyzed using Raman. The peaks of F2g and A1g of Co3O4 were observed at 512 and 680 cm−1, respectively [56,57]. This agreed with XRD results. The catalytic performance of catalysts The activity and stability measurements of all prepared samples were summarized in Figs. 5 and 6 . The DRM reaction with loading 0.5 g of catalysts under a CH4/CO2 flow of 60/60 mL/min was carried out on the previously prepared catalysts. The variation of catalytic performance of all prepared samples with temperature was examined in two temperature intervals of warming (650–850 °C) and cooling (850–650 °C). From Fig. 5, the values of CH4 and CO2 conversion, H2/CO and H2 and CO selectivity exhibited a positive trend with the reaction temperature. It was explained by the temperature-sensitive property of the DRM reaction [58]. There was an increment of energy in the reaction system with increasing temperature so as to give reactant molecules enough kinetic energy to move. The lively motion of reactant molecules increased the chance of coming into contact with the catalytic center. The catalytic performance of Y-NC-XCo displayed a growing trend as the loading of Co increased. The best catalytic performance was discovered over Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst suggested that Ce acted as a favorable promoter for Co. Combining with the characterization results, it was believed that the addition of Ce enhanced the availability of Co catalytic sites. In contrast with its performance during the warming temperature interval, the catalyst's performance dropped during the cooling temperature interval. This was attributed to the irreversible damage to the catalyst as a result of coke deposition and metal sintering. It must be pointed out that Y-NC-20Co-Ce still performs the most remarkable catalytic activity during the cooling temperature interval. The increased activity of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst contributed to the high loading and high dispersion of Co particles. The addition of the promoter Ce made an outstanding contribution to the improvement of the loading and dispersibility of Co particles. Meanwhile, the oxygen-rich vacancies in Y-NC-20Co-5Ce helped it to resist carbon deposition. The plots in Fig. 6a and 6b illustrated the CH4 and CO2 conversions of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce were 83.7 % and 92.7 %, respectively, in the assessment of the catalytic performance in relation to time. Among the prepared catalysts, Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst not only maintained the most exceptional CH4 and CO2 conversion, but also had high selectivity of H2 and CO (Figs. 5d,e and 6d,e). This was consistent with the carbon balance of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce being closest to 1, which suggested that the least side reactions occur on the Y-NC-20Co-5Ce surface (Figs. 5f and 6f). The characterization of spent catalysts To evaluate the contribution of Ce addition to the prepared samples anti-deactivation, all spent catalysts were examined and evaluated by XPS, XRD, TEM and TG. XRD experimental data were summarized in Fig. 7 a. All catalysts displayed peaks at around 25.2° and 43° for the (002) and (100) plane of graphitic carbon, respectively. The (200) plane of Co was given to the small peak at 51.5° in the XRD patterns of all spent catalysts. This could due to the excess electrons being transferred from the defective structure to Co2+ and Co3+. The XPS results also supported the same conclusion. There were diffraction peaks of Co° for all the spent catalysts, which were illustrated in Fig. 7b. XPS spectra of O1s was conducted to understand oxygen context in the sample. The different kinds of oxygen found in the spent catalysts were presented in Fig. 7c. The Oα peak of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce disappeared in comparison with the catalyst that was not added with Ce. It was probably resulted from the release of lattice oxygen from the metal oxide forming oxygen vacancies that transform to chemisorbed oxygen [59]. From Fig. 7d, the Ce 3d area was classified into Ce 3d3/2 orbitals represented by the U peak and Ce 3d5/2 orbitals represented by the V peaks [48]. The peaks of u′ and v′ were categorized to Ce3+ while the remaining peaks were categorized as Ce4+ [45,46,48,60]. The Ce3+/Ce3++Ce4+ ratio of fresh and spent Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst were derived from the regional integration of the convolution peaks in Fig. 4d and Fig. 7d, respectively. Fresh catalyst exhibited a Ce3+/Ce3++Ce4+ proportion of 0.264, while spent catalyst held a Ce3+/Ce3++Ce4+ proportion of 0.453. Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies were developed simultaneously, so the valence shift of Ce modified the oxygen environment in the catalyst [49]. This facilitated the CO2 to be attract and activated [61]. TG analysis to clarify the anti-carbon deposition performance of Y-NC-20Co and Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalysts, which were presented in Fig. 7e and 7f. Y-NC-20Co-5Ce exhibited better resistance to carbon deposition than Y-NC-20Co, with mass loss of 44.3 and 81.3 % for the two samples, respectively (Fig. 7e). The DTG curves of Y-NC-20Co and Y-NC-20Co-5Ce also appeared significantly different, with Y-NC-20Co presenting endothermic peaks at 324 °C and 427 °C additionally a peak at 549 °C (Fig. 7f). It was probably due to the vacancy in the oxygen-deficient state of the Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst removed some of the carbon deposition. The TEM data (Fig. 8 a and 8c) and the size distribution of Co (Fig. 8b and 8d) were explored to examine the alteration of Co particle diameter after the DRM reaction. For Y-NC-20Co, the Co particles had a diameter of about 17.90 nm (Fig. 8b). While for Y-NC-20Co-5Ce, the average diameter of Co particles grew to 13.35 nm after 10 h DRM reaction (Fig. 8d). Y-NC-20Co-5Ce still maintained a small active metal particle diameter. In accordance with the previous analysis, the presence of Ce contributed to the catalyst become anti-coke deposited. This prevented the sintering of active metal Co to some point. As the coke deposition would pull Co particles out of the support, causing the metal to separate from the support [62]. In summary, for the Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst, Ce species enhanced the distribution of Co particles and diminished the diameter of Co particles, as shown in Fig. 9 . It helped the defective structure to play an anchoring role to the active metal Co. It was more efficient to play the limiting role of defective structure and enhance the efficiency of utilizing Co. The more crucial was the elevated level of chemisorbed oxygen, which enhanced the attraction and reactivation of the reaction gas. The resulting reactive oxygen species then interact with carbon-containing materials to prevent the accumulation of carbon species. Thus, Y-NC-20Co-5Ce demonstrated a better capability to catalyze the DRM reaction compared to Y-NC-20Co. Compared to other metal-carbon material support catalysts, Y-NC-20Co-5Ce also showed excellent competitiveness (Table S1). It can be found that the CH4 and CO2 conversions of previously reported metal-carbon material support catalysts decrease significantly at larger GHSV. Comparatively, CH4 and CO2 conversions of Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst can still respectively maintain 83.7 % and 92.7 % after 24 h reaction with a total GHSV of 14,400 mL gcat −1h−1. Moreover, the actual CH4 and CO2 conversion of the Y-NC-20Co-5Ce catalyst is lower than its thermodynamic equilibrium conversion (Table S2), which indicates that the active centers on the catalyst surface are working efficiently [63]. Conclusion In this paper, defect-rich biomass carbon materials were prepared using a nitrogen introduction-evaporation process and utilized as supports for Co-based catalysts. And the Co-Ce bimetallic catalysts were obtained by further loading Ce on the Co-based carbon material catalysts to catalyze the DRM reaction. The defects in the carbon structure provided anchoring sites for the Co species, preventing their migration and agglomeration. The higher cobalt content and good cobalt dispersion provided more active sites for the DRM reaction. The presence of Ce in the catalyst formulation facilitates the distribution of active metal Co in the defective structure, resulting in improved dispersion of Co species on the catalyst surface. This enhanced dispersion led to a higher number of active sites and improved catalytic activity of the catalysts. In addition, the formation process of Ce3+ ions were accompanied by the creation of oxygen vacancies, which increased the amount of chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst. The increase in chemisorbed oxygen content on the catalyst surface promoted the adsorption and activation of CO2, enhancing the catalysts’ resistance to carbon deposition. These effects collectively contributed to the improved catalytic performance of Co-Ce bimetallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis and utilization of defect-rich biomass carbon catalysts with varying Co concentrations and incorporated Ce in CH4-CO2 reforming were investigated. The catalytic performance of these catalysts was found to increase with higher Co content, reaching its optimum at a Co concentration of 20 %. The presence of Ce as a promoter improved the utilization of Co precursors and enhanced the dispersion of Co sites at defective structures on the catalyst surface. The confined space within the defective structures restricted the growth of Co particles, resulting in smaller and more uniformly dispersed Co particles on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the introduction of Ce species influenced the oxygen environment on the catalyst surface. XPS analysis confirmed that the addition of Ce led to an increase in the chemisorbed oxygen content, enhancing the catalyst's ability to activate CO2. The increased percentage of chemisorbed oxygen, coupled with improved CO2 activation capacity, contributed to the Co-Ce bimetallic catalyst's ability to resist carbon deposition. The Co-Ce bimetallic catalyst demonstrated exceptional stability and performance in CH4-CO2 reforming due to its enhanced metal dispersion, reduced metal particle size, and improved CO2 activation capacity. The incorporation of Ce as a promoter played a crucial role in achieving these desirable catalytic properties.
coredata.dc:title: Co-based defect-rich nanoarchitectonics with biomass carbon materials catalysts for CH4–CO2 reforming
